Harlequin and Friar Bacon

Table of contents

    “Harlequin and Friar Bacon” is a British pantomime play from the collection of Glenn Hughes who used the collection in the 1930s and 1940s as a tool for research and teaching his students in the drama program at the University of Washington. It comes from a collection of over 3,000 plays, the majority British. It is likely that “Harlequin and Friar Bacon” belongs to the subset within the collection of works added from a single contributing collection, all of which were made as sales or gifts to the audience of a performance, mainly consisting of Christmas extravaganzas, pantomimes, and burlesques. Pantomimes are usually performed around Christmas and are comedies that often include slapstick humor, jokes, innuendos, magic, fairies, and gender reversal.

    The focus of our edition of “Harlequin and Friar Bacon” is digitizing the original play to become accessible to actors and students who are interested in its content, whether that be for purposes of studying drama or gleaning an understanding of the content of historical plays. Pantomimes are still performed in the United States but with less frequency and popularity than in England, so the edition will also function to introduce actors to studies of plays on a global scale.

    Our edition features a transcription which is intended to maintain as much of the original content as possible, including preserving the British spellings for words as opposed to Americanizing them. Racial slurs have been redacted and given note in the end notes if relevant to understanding the passage. Any italics and bold are preserved as they are displayed in the original play. In the original print, advertisements line the jacket and are interspersed throughout the text, which have not been preserved in this digital edition because it is not intended for viewing by audiences but by actors.

    1.

    • Robin Goodfellows
      Note:

      In English folklore, The Puck, also known as Goodfellows, are/is a domestic and nature sprite, demon, or fairy.

    • Oberon
      Note:

      Oberon is a king of the fairies in medieval and Renaissance literature. He is best known as a character in William Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream, in which he is King of the Fairies and spouse of Titania, Queen of the Fairies.

    • Harry Bailly or Harry Bailey
      Note:

      The Host is a character who plays a key role in and throughout Geoffrey Chaucer's The Canterbury Tales. He is the owner of the Tabard Inn in London, where the pilgrimage begins and he agrees to travel on the pilgrimage, and promises to judge both the tales the pilgrims tell, and disputes among the pilgrims.

    • Geoffrey Chaucer1340s25 October 1400
      Note:

      Geoffrey Chaucer was an English poet, author, and civil servant best known for The Canterbury Tales. He has been called the "father of English literature", or, alternatively, the "father of English poetry".

    • John of Gaunt 6 March 13403 February 1399
      Note:

      John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster was an English royal prince, military leader, and statesman. He was the fourth son of King Edward III of England, and the father of King Henry IV.
